en: Interview with Marty Pryor, 2020-01-09

Interview with Marty Pryor, retired social worker and volunteer with the Red Cross. Pryor discusses the aid she provided during the relief efforts of the wildfires. She also talks about the ways in which the community bonded during and after the disaster. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Now in all situations when a human organism goes through an emotional trauma, one of the needs is to tell their story. We are social beings and we talk, and that's one reason you all are doing this project: our social history is very important. And everybody has a story to tell."

Description

Interview with Marty Pryor, retired social worker and volunteer with the Red Cross. Pryor discusses the aid she provided during the relief efforts of the wildfires. She also talks about the ways in which the community bonded during and after the disaster. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Now in all situations when a human organism goes through an emotional trauma, one of the needs is to tell their story. We are social beings and we talk, and that's one reason you all are doing this project: our social history is very important. And everybody has a story to tell."

Captions in English
Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Marty Pryor, 2020-01-09
Interview Questions
How long have you been in East Tennessee?
Can you tell us about how you got involved in the Red Cross and your role there?
When did you first realize there was a fire in Gatlinburg?
What was the nature of the original call?
So you were alerted at that point?
Where was the office that was opened?
On Tuesday morning the offices opened, what happened after that?
Once the office is up and going, who started to come through the door?
Did you go to Gatlinburg?
Who from the fire came in?
When the Red Cross met with the survivors, what did you see?
What kind of trauma and distress did you see?
So the survivors were in shock? Did they know where they were? Were they fazed?
What were some of the needs or questions that people were bringing?
What did the Red Cross do for these survivors?
Did these people go into town to retriece pets?
Did yo go into Gatlinburg with any of the people that lost their homes? Did any of the other case workers?
Can you illustrate a typical case? What you might have seen and worked through?
From the mental health aspect, how did case workers help survivors?
You said that Red Cross had a headquarters opened for 3 to 4 week following the fire?
How did the people in Gatlinburg respond to the fire opposed to other disasters you've seen?
Do you think the people you encountered were resilient?
Have you kept in touch with any of these people since the fire?
Have you kept in touch with any of these people since the fire?
Some of those people in the service industry, not only did they lose their home, but their employer shut down?
What are your assessments of the long term efforts?
Can you compare the Chimney Top II Wildfires with other disasters that you experienced?
What is the emotional impact from this kind of wildfire event?
So part of the treatment was listening to their story about going through the fire?
People talk about Gatlinburg being Mountain Tough, were these survivors tougher than other individuals you have seen in disasters?
You mention that Mountain Tough was a bonding motto, how do you think this fire shaped community relations in Gatlinburg?
Why did your caseload triple after the fire?
Is Gatlinburg, or the Smokies, better prepared for another disaster?
Did you see anything good or surprising that came ouf of the fire?
Was the fire a good opportunity to observe social behavior?
Are you seeing vicarious traumatization in our caseload?
Is there anything else you would like to share?
